part_of: Precursor Movements to Latin American Independence

causes: Increased taxation by Spanish colonial authorities
Economic hardship due to Spanish mercantilist policies
Resentment towards Spanish monopolies on goods like tobacco and liquor
Growing influence of Enlightenment ideas on self-governance
events_leading_up_to_war: Implementation of new sales taxes and tariffs in early 1781
Peasants, artisans, and indigenous groups unite against Spanish officials
The uprising begins in Socorro, with local leaders calling for resistance
Rebel forces march towards Bogotá, gaining mass support along the way

result.general: Spanish colonial forces suppress the rebellion through deception and force
result.treaty: False concessions granted by Viceroy Manuel Antonio Flórez before retracting them
result.territorial_changes: New Granada remains under Spanish rule

entities: Spanish colonial government in New Granada

Comunero_Rebels.weapons: Improvised weapons, farming tools, some firearms

Comunero_Rebels.civilian_losses: Mass arrests and targeted reprisals against rebel sympathizers

major_battles.name: March to Bogotá
major_battles.description: Comunero rebels advanced towards the capital, forcing the Spanish authorities to negotiate.

major_battles.name: Battle of Zipaquirá
major_battles.description: Spanish forces feigned agreement with rebels, only to later launch a brutal crackdown.
major_battles.outcome: Spanish deception leads to rebel collapse

major_battles.name: Final Executions
major_battles.description: Leaders of the revolt, including José Antonio Galán, are captured and publicly executed.

terms: Execution of rebel leaders, including quartering of José Antonio Galán
Mass imprisonment and forced labor for rebel sympathizers
Strengthening of Spanish military presence in New Granada
impact: Short-term stability restored in New Granada
Harsh Spanish policies fuel long-term revolutionary sentiment
Inspiration for later independence movements in the early 19th century

long_term_effects: Increased rejection of Spanish colonial rule
Seen as a precursor to Simón Bolívar’s wars of independence

economic: Temporary Spanish relaxation of harsh taxes
Continued exploitation of colonial resources by the Spanish crown
political: Inspired later uprisings in Spanish America
Exposed Spanish vulnerability in governing distant colonies
social: Increased political consciousness among lower classes
First major attempt at multi-ethnic anti-colonial resistance in New Granada
